channel.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Does Andrew Tate dress like Kamala Harris? Expert's observation breaking internet
item.description: ​ Andrew Tate's rant against Kamala Harris went viral for a different reason after a menswear writer pointed out that Andrew Tate actually dresses like Kamala Harris -- similar shades, similar pantsuits. Tate's fans did not like the comparison though maximum reactions were of amusement as users found out that their dressing do actually match.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Georgia School Shooting: JD Vance campaign slams AP for ‘brazenly lying’
item.description: "This is yet another case of the fake news media brazenly lying about a Republican politician. Senator Vance said exactly the opposite of what the Associated Press claimed. It should come as no surprise that the AP lost any and all credibility it had years ago, because they will lie about literally anything in order prop up the Democrats. Meanwhile, Kamala Harris has called for all police officers to be removed from schools, putting children all over America at risk. It's yet another example of how Kamala Harris's weak, failed, and dangerously liberal agenda makes her unfit for office.”
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: How Kate Middleton is preparing Prince George to become King
item.description: A key part of this preparation involves gradually exposing George to royal duties and events. "He is attending royal events such as Trooping the Colour, the Coronation, and big set events, and he is slowly being introduced to those," Dampier noted.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: French mass rape suspect among 'worst sexual criminals', says daughter
item.description: Dominique Pelicot, a 71-year-old retiree from France, faces trial for drugging his wife and arranging for strangers to rape her over nearly a decade. His daughter labeled him one of the worst sexual criminals in recent memory. The case has horrified France, with numerous suspects potentially facing up to 20 years in prison if found guilty.

item.title: Never-seen-before footage of JFK assassination shot by a Texas businessman emerges: What we know
item.description: Carpenter's grandson, James Gates, said the film was not much talked about in the family though everyone knew about it. Gates said he came into the possession of the film in 2009 or 2010 when his mother handed him a milk crate that had some 30 film reels including this one. When he first viewed the Kennedy footage, he was underwhelmed as it did not show Kennedy but he was struck by Hill's bravery.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Pope Francis arrives in Papua New Guinea, country two of 12-day trip
item.description: Pope Francis arrived in Papua New Guinea from Indonesia on Friday evening, continuing his extensive 12-day tour across Southeast Asia and Oceania. Greeted by Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso, he will address political leaders and visit Vanimo before traveling to East Timor and Singapore. The pope's visit emphasizes environmental issues, including climate change.

item.title: Paetongtarn Shinawatra sworn in as new Thai PM
item.description: Thailand swore Paetongtarn Shinawatra in as prime minister on Friday, capping a month of political tumult that saw her predecessor thrown out of office and the main opposition party dissolved. Paetongtarn took the oath in a closed-15 pm (1115 GMT), officially becoming Thailand's youngest-ever prime minister. bur-srg/ssy

item.title: UK court jails people trafficker for 10 years
item.description: A British court has sentenced Anas al-Mustafa to 10 years in prison for smuggling seven migrants in a hidden van compartment. The migrants, discovered on a ship from France to England, were found in dire conditions, suffering from dehydration and other severe health issues. This case underscores the perils faced by individuals attempting illegal entry into the UK.

item.title: Sweden joins countries seeking to end screen time for children under 2
item.description: Sweden's public health agency recommends that children under 2 should avoid digital screens entirely, with limited screen time for older age groups. Similar guidelines are seen in other countries including the US, Ireland, Canada, Australia, and France. Concerns focus on negative impacts on sleep, mental health, and physical activity. Policymakers call for tech companies to adjust algorithms to protect children.

item.title: Man jailed for 9 years for setting fire to asylum seekers' hotel in UK anti-Muslim riots
item.description: Thomas Birley, aged 27, received a nine-year prison sentence for arson at a hotel housing asylum seekers amid anti-Muslim riots. He admitted to starting the fire with intent to endanger life. The unrest was sparked by misinformation after the killings of three girls in Southport, leading to widespread violence and arrests.

item.title: UK appoints former PM Blair's top aide to lead talks on control of Chagos Islands
item.description: Britain has named Jonathan Powell, ex-chief of staff to Tony Blair, as its special envoy for negotiations with Mauritius regarding the Chagos Islands' sovereignty. Detached from Mauritius in 1965, these islands host a crucial US military base on Diego Garcia. The British government seeks to maintain this base's long-term operations while addressing Mauritius' claims.

item.title: One dead, dozens injured in Russian strikes on Ukraine's Pavlograd
item.description: Russian missile strikes on Pavlograd in central Ukraine killed one person and injured more than 50 others, including three children. Five Iskander ballistic missiles were fired, causing several fires in the city. This attack is part of increased Russian aerial assaults following Ukraine's cross-border offensive into Russia's Kursk region last month.

item.title: 'Terror threat': Indonesia arrests seven over failed plot to attack Pope Francis
item.description: Indonesian authorities have arrested seven individuals for issuing online terror threats against Pope Francis during his visit aimed at promoting religious unity. Heightened security measures include around 4,000 personnel to ensure the pope's safety. The suspects are accused of posting bomb threats on social media concerning the pope's public meetings in Jakarta.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Pakistan's capital reports first poliovirus case in last 16 years, 17 cases reported so far this year
item.description: Pakistan has confirmed its first polio case in Islamabad in over 16 years, marking the nation's 17th case this year. In response, a nationwide vaccination campaign will start on September 9, aiming to immunize over 33 million children under five. Authorities stress the need for parental cooperation to curb further outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kamala Harris' August fundraising hits $404 million, pushing her ahead of Trump
item.description: Kamala Harris's campaign and the Democratic Party raised $361 million in August, providing a financial advantage over Donald Trump with two months until Election Day. At the start of September, Harris had $404 million in cash on hand. Both candidates are projected to spend over $1 billion as they target key battleground states.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Revival of SAARC spirit can solve many regional problems: Bangladesh's Chief Adviser Yunus
item.description: Muhammad Yunus, head of Bangladesh's interim government, advocates for reviving SAARC to tackle regional issues. He intends to meet Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi during the UN General Assembly and aims to gather SAARC leaders for a photo op. Yunus also seeks India's help in addressing the Rohingya crisis impacting Bangladesh.

item.title: 'Psychopath' sets girlfriend's parents' home on fire after dispute in New Jersey
item.description: In South Brunswick, Leonard Jones, 50, allegedly set fire to his girlfriend's parents' home after an argument. The incident took place around 3 a.m., prompting police response. All four residents managed to escape safely as the fire engulfed the house. Jones was subsequently arrested and charged with aggravated arson and domestic violence.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Zelenskyy meets top military leaders in Germany as the US announces additional aid to Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with U.S. military leaders and over 50 partner nations in Germany to push for more weapons support. The U.S. announced an additional $250 million in security aid for Ukraine. Discussions focused on air defense, artillery supplies, and enhancing Ukraine's defense industrial base as Zelenskyy seeks long-range strike capabilities.

item.title: 'School shooting.. I'm scared': Parents and students share heart-wrenching messages during Apalachee high attack in Georgia
item.description: A tragic shooting occurred at Apalachee High School in Winder, Georgia, killing four people and injuring nine others. Students sent desperate texts to their parents during the lockdown. The alleged shooter is a 14-year-old student who now faces multiple charges. Victims include two teachers and two students.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Wanted to play like other children': Roller-skater Gaza girl’s life cut short in Israeli airstrike
item.description: Hussam Salah Abu Ajwa let his daughter Tala play outside in Gaza City, but an explosion killed her moments later. The conflict has ravaged the area, damaging schools and displacing families. UNRWA cautions that ongoing violence may result in a generation marked by resentment and extremism due to the prolonged conflict.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
